div.l: They ween no man may hem be gile
But be my thryfft ȝit shal I blere hir ey
For al their scleyȝt and philosophy
The more queynt mokkis that they make
The more woll I stele when I take
I stede of flour͗e I woll gyve hem brenne
The grettest Clerkis been nat wisest men
As whilom they spak on to the mare
Of al ther͗e arte I count nat a tare
Out atte dorr he went pryvely
And when he saw his tyme sofftely
He lokid vp ⁊and down til he foıı̄unde
The clerkis hors wher͗e they were bound
By hynd the Mill vndir the leff sele
And to the hors he goith feir ⁊and wele
And stripith of the bridillis ⁊and þat anoon
And when the hors were lose þey gan to goon
This Iohn goith forth ⁊and fyndith his hors a wey
And gon cry harow ⁊and welawey
Our͗e hors be lost Aleyn by kokkis bonys
Stepe out thy fete com of al attonys
Allas our warden hath his hors lorn
This Aleyn forgate both mele ⁊and corn
Al was out of his mynde his husbondry
What wich wey is he goon he gan cry
The wyff cam rennyng out atta ren
She seyd Allas they go in to the fen
With wild maris as fast as they may goo
Vnthank com on his hond þᵗat vnbond hem so
And he that bet shuld have knet the reyn
Allas quod ⁊and Iohn ⁊and Alen for cristis peyn
Ley down thy swerd ⁊and I wol myne also
I is ful swyfft God woot as eny Roo
Be goddis sawle he shal nat scape vs bath
